Award.AwardTitle: III: Medium: Hardware/Software Accelerated Data Mining for Real-Time Monitoring of Streaming Pediatric ICU Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
On any given day in America, there are at least one thousand children fighting for their lives in Pediatric Intensive Care Units (PICUs). In the PICU the patient's condition is carefully monitored with automatic sensors. Most of this data is shown in a five-minute "sliding window" display, so a doctor summoned to a patient's bedside always has her most recent history to consider. However what happens to the data that "falls off" this sliding window? In most PICUs, a tiny fraction of it is coarsely aggregated and recorded, but surprisingly, most of this data is simply discarded. Even if most or all the data is recorded, its sheer volume simply overwhelms researchers and analysts; very few tools exist to help them make sense of and learn from this data. This currently discarded data is a potential goldmine of actionable knowledge that could improve outcomes (decreased mortality/morbidity, reduce pain, etc.), and reduce costs (implicit in reduced length of stay). However, the very nature of this data - multivariate, heterogeneous, high dimensional, temporal, noisy, biased, and high frequency - poses significant challenges for traditional analytical techniques from statistics and data mining.

In this project, an interdisciplinary team of investigators is developing: (a) xcalable machine learning algorithms for mining archives of annotated PICU data to find regularities and patterns that can be used to aid in diagnostics and prediction of outcomes; and (b) techniques for monitoring ICU telemetry in real time to detect whether the patterns and rules discovered in the offline step have occurred and can be used to guide interventions (actions by the doctor).

The project brings together experts in data mining (Keogh, Tsotras), high performance computing (Najjar), and medicine (Wetzel) to investigate holistic solutions to the above problems. The project contributes to research-based advanced training of graduate and undergraduate students at the University of California Riverside. The findings, datasets, software, and teaching materials created by this project will be archived in perpetuity at www.cs.ucr.edu/~eamonn/UCRPICU/

Institution.Name: University of California-Riverside
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA AT RIVERSIDE

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed algorithms and data representations to allow people to process and ultimately understand large amounts of “time series” data. Familiar examples of time series data include heartbeats and brainwaves, but time series data is pervasive in almost all human endeavors, including medicine, science, industry and finance.

The ideas produced by the project allow users to find predictive rules in the data, for example: “If you see this type of decline in blood sugar level, then within one hour you will see a spike in blood pressure”. Such IF-THEN rules can be applied not only to medicine, but to industry. For example, discovering a rule in an oil distillation-column time series that says, “If pressure declines AND temperature increases, then warn plant manager: avoidable and costly foaming event is imminent.”

The algorithms developed have been used worldwide by researchers, medical start-ups, and by several large companies including Mitsubishi Labs (Boston) Oracle, Samsung (San Jose) Applied Materials and AspenTech.

More than a dozen students (the majority of which came from NSF defined underrepresented groups) were partly or completely funded by this award. Most have graduated and gone on to careers in academia (including the University of New Mexico, and Kasetsart University Thailand), or to industry, including such top companies such as Google, Facebook, Apple, Samsung and Teradata.

The project produced many papers in top venues. Because of publication lags, it is difficult to measure the impact of the more recent papers. However, one of the first papers published under the auspices of this award, is the most cited paper SIGKDD (the top venue for data mining research), in the year it was published. We fully expect at least some of the more recent papers to have a similar impact.

In addition, the project produced many resources which will have a long life beyond the end of this projects funding. Datasets and code produced continue to be download (and later cited) at least a dozen times a month. Tutorials created and presented by the PIs have been adapted as teaching materials and used in dozens of classrooms worldwide, and the PIs have created relationships advising several medical start-ups that are exploiting the research to produce medical devices that can reduce mortality and morbidly for several medical conditions.

Finally, as part of the PIs commitment to outreach, the PIs both visited K12 schools, and hosted K12 students as visitors to the university labs, to communicate the fun and excitement of working in a STEM field. 

 


Last Modified: 08/29/2017
Modified by: Eamonn Keogh
